commits.message: Add index and link to RSS feed
Add scripts to fetch weather and repos

forkee.name: hugo-alabaster-theme
forkee.description: A documentation theme ported from Sphinx to Hugo

comment.body:
Hey VÃ­tor,

This script isn't for zipping workflows, just the library.

It only includes *.py files, `version` and `Notify.tgz` in any case.

I think you're thinking of [this script](https://gist.github.com/deanishe/b16f018119ef3fe951af), which should be updated to strip unexported variables.

commits.message:
Alfred 3 and new data model

- Migrate to Alfred 3 and Workflow3
- Reorganise data & scripts
- New engine data model
  - Load engines from Python modules
  - Load engines from JSON files
Pre-commit hook to keep API key out of repo
Hook rejects commit if API key present

issue.title: Autosuggest for Google Maps broken
issue.body:
Seems like the autosuggest for Google Maps no longer works.  Did the Google API endpoint change for that?

![screen shot 2016-11-27 at 8 25 36 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5793364/20648376/bd0359b4-b4df-11e6-82cd-3051d15ba8e2.png)

comment.body:
I've sorta fixed this.

The maps autosuggest API has been turned off, so I've replaced with with the Places API. The upshot is, you need to get an API key for that one :(

Google Maps is working on the `develop` branch, but some engines are still missing or half-implemented.

issue.title: exclude certain languages?
issue.body: Is this possible? Some of the the unicode icons are coming up as question marks (not found I am assuming), whilst others are irrelevant and will never be used...

comment.body:
The question mark means the symbol isn't supported by the font you have set (Arial Unicode by default).

I suppose it would be possible to exclude certain alphabets or codepoint ranges.

The trick would be identifying them.

release.name: Smarter SSH URLs
release.body:
- [Smarter generation of SSH URLs for hosts from `~/.ssh/config`](http://www.alfredforum.com/topic/8956-secure-shell-for-alfred-3-ssh-plus-sftp-mosh-ping-with-autosuggest/?do=findComment&comment=49170)
- Better removal of duplicates

issue.title: Include pint's spectroscopy (and other context) option(s)
issue.body: Great tool! It would be really nice to also take advantage of the more advanced conversions already available in pint, such as converting between energy and length in the context of spectroscopy (e.g., 1 Ã = 12398 eV for light).

comment.body:
Right, I've got you. Contexts are not currently supported.

I'm afraid this is over my head mathematically speaking. Could you give me a couple of examples of conversions that should work (`sp 1Ã ev` -> `12398 eV` perhaps?), and I'll adjust the parser to allow a context as the first argument.

issue.title: How best to support workflow variables?
issue.body:
So in Alfred 3 you can set variables from your Script Filter results by setting `arg` to a JSON-encoded `{"alfredworkflow":{"arg":...}}` dictionary.

I've been exploring this mechanism in a [Go library](https://gogs.deanishe.net/deanishe/awgo) (Go's a PITA for this, btw). How I currently have that one working is that you can set variables at the `Workflow`, `Item` or `Modifier` level. When you create a new `Item` or `Modifier`, it inherits its parent's variables _at the time of creation_. So you can do:

``` go
wf.SetVar("api_key", api_key) // Inherited by all child Items

it := wf.NewItem("Item Title")
it.Subtitle = "Open in New Window"
it.SetVar("uuid", uuid)  // Inherited by child Modifiers

// CMD
m := it.NewModifier("cmd")
m.Subtitle = "Open in New Tab"
m.SetVar("open_in_tab", "1")

// ALT
m = it.NewModifier("alt")
m.Subtitle = "Open in Private Window"
m.SetVar("open_in_private", "1")

it.SetVar("open_in_win", "1") // Only set on Item, not Modifiers
```

Is that a solid solution for Alfred-Workflow? Too complex? Should variables (and arg) be resolved at feedback-generation time instead (i.e. `vars = wf.vars.copy(); vars.update(item.vars); vars.update(mod.vars)`)?

Or is variable inheritance a fundamentally bad idea?

Could maybe even make different `Feedback` classes with different variable inheritance behaviour.

comment.body:
Will do. I'll have to have a think about how best to handle workflow and environment variables.

The implementation changed in 6b1fc2c, as Alfred 3.2 added "real" top-level workflow variables Previously `Workflow3.setvar()` was just a convenience to set variables on all `Item3` objects. Now it really sets top-level workflow variables (not that there's a lot of difference in practice).

I suspect what @ViViDboarder suggested is how most people would expect and/or prefer it to work, but I'm leery of conflating the "real" environment (i.e. `os.environ`) and workflow variables too much because they're not the same. For example, `$HOME` isn't a workflow variable (i.e. you can't do `{var:HOME}` in an Args & Vars Utility).

If `Workflow3.getvar()` gets a value from `os.environ`, should it "import" the variable, so it *is* set for downstream workflow objects (e.g. `Workflow.getvar('HOME')` would automatically make `{var:HOME}` work downstream)? If not, a user might think they're using a workflow variable when it's actually from `os.environ` and won't be visible to downstream objects.

If `Workflow3.getvar()` reads from `os.environ`, should `Workflow3.setvar()` also write to `os.environ` (so the variables would also be set when you call `run_in_background()` or `subprocess.call()`, and not just for downstream objects)?

issue.title: How best to support workflow variables?
issue.body:
So in Alfred 3 you can set variables from your Script Filter results by setting `arg` to a JSON-encoded `{"alfredworkflow":{"arg":...}}` dictionary.

I've been exploring this mechanism in a [Go library](https://gogs.deanishe.net/deanishe/awgo) (Go's a PITA for this, btw). How I currently have that one working is that you can set variables at the `Workflow`, `Item` or `Modifier` level. When you create a new `Item` or `Modifier`, it inherits its parent's variables _at the time of creation_. So you can do:

``` go
wf.SetVar("api_key", api_key) // Inherited by all child Items

it := wf.NewItem("Item Title")
it.Subtitle = "Open in New Window"
it.SetVar("uuid", uuid)  // Inherited by child Modifiers

// CMD
m := it.NewModifier("cmd")
m.Subtitle = "Open in New Tab"
m.SetVar("open_in_tab", "1")

// ALT
m = it.NewModifier("alt")
m.Subtitle = "Open in Private Window"
m.SetVar("open_in_private", "1")

it.SetVar("open_in_win", "1") // Only set on Item, not Modifiers
```

Is that a solid solution for Alfred-Workflow? Too complex? Should variables (and arg) be resolved at feedback-generation time instead (i.e. `vars = wf.vars.copy(); vars.update(item.vars); vars.update(mod.vars)`)?

Or is variable inheritance a fundamentally bad idea?

Could maybe even make different `Feedback` classes with different variable inheritance behaviour.

comment.body: I explained this in the comment above yours. A newly-created `Workflows3` object has no variables.
